title: 106_hr515
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act". The Congress finds that in the 10 years from 1987 through 1996, nearly 2,200 children in the United States aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings. The United States leads the industrialized world in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death. The United States has the highest rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death compared to other industrialized countries. A 1997 study found the US rate was 9 times greater than 25 other countries combined. Additionally, the number of nonfatal unintentional firearm injuries in US children treated in hospitals annually is nearly 8 times higher than the number of deaths. In the United States, the number of nonfatal unintentional gunshot wounds in children treated in hospitals annually is nearly 8 times higher than the number of deaths. Handguns are most often involved in unintentional gunshot wounds among children in California. A study in the December 1995 issue of the Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine found that children as young as 3 years old are strong enough to fire most commercially available handguns. The study revealed that 25 percent of 3- to 4-year-olds and 70 percent of 5- to 6-year-olds had sufficient finger strength to fire 59 out of 64 handguns examined. The study found that young children have sufficient finger strength to fire most available handguns. Firearms in the US are not subject to minimum safety standards. A 1997 poll showed that 74% of Americans support gun safety measures. A 1997 poll found that 74% of Americans support safety regulation of the firearms industry, as many trigger locks are inadequate to prevent accidental discharge. Firearms and safety locks involved in interstate commerce. Many trigger locks and similar devices are ineffective in preventing accidental firearm discharge or children from accessing the firearms, especially those involved in interstate commerce. Regulation of handgun discharge protection products. The Secretary of the Treasury will regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children. Regulations will include a minimum safety standard for these products. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish a minimum safety standard for handgun discharge protection products to prevent children from operating a handgun. The standard will ensure quality and construction to meet the requirements of the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish a standard for handgun discharge protection products to prevent children from operating a handgun. The standard will require quality construction and the use of specific access methods. The Secretary will establish a standard for handgun discharge protection products to prevent children from operating a handgun, considering poison prevention packaging standards. The standard must be issued within 12 months of the enactment of the Act and will take effect 6 months after issuance. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of a handgun discharge protection product that violates the Act. They can also require the recall, repair, replacement, or refunds for products found in violation. The manufacturer and dealer of a handgun discharge protection product found in violation of the Act must provide notice of risks to the public and other parties involved. The manufacturer and dealer of a handgun discharge protection product found in violation of the Act must take actions such as bringing the product into compliance, repairing or replacing it, or refunding the purchase price. The manufacturer and dealer must take actions to comply with regulations, including refunding the purchase price or recalling the product. The Secretary may conduct inspections to ensure compliance with the Act. The Secretary may conduct inspections to ensure compliance with the Act by entering places where handgun discharge protection products are manufactured, stored, or transported for commercial purposes. SEC. 5. UNLAWFUL ACTS. Beginning 30 days after a final standard is issued, it is unlawful for licensed manufacturers or importers to sell handguns without a discharge protection product, and for licensed dealers to sell handguns without the protection product supplied by the manufacturer or importer. An exception is made for sales to government departments or agencies. Licensed manufacturers or importers cannot sell handguns without a discharge protection product, and licensed dealers cannot sell handguns without the protection product supplied by the manufacturer or importer. However, this does not apply to sales to government departments or agencies. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. In accordance with SEC. 6, handgun packaging must include a warning label on the principal display panel and accompanying materials. The label must contain a specific statement in conspicuous and legible type. The warning label required for handgun packaging must contain a statement about the dangers of children accessing and operating handguns, emphasizing the need to keep them locked and unloaded. The appearance of the warning label on handgun packaging must contrast with other printed matter, similar to regulations in effect as of January 1, 1998. Handguns cannot be sold without accompanying packaging or descriptive materials. The law requires a warning label to be affixed to handguns when transferred without packaging. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's injury or death from a handgun sold after the Act's effective date.

SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary may assess civil penalties up to $10,000 for violations of the Act and revoke federal firearms licenses for violations. Additionally, individuals have a private cause of action for any Act violations. The Handgun Injury Prevention Act allows for private cause of action in United States district courts for damages, including attorney's fees, against violators of the Act or its regulations. The Handgun Injury Prevention Act allows for private enforcement in US district courts for damages, including attorney's fees, and provides remedies in addition to other laws. Private enforcement of the Handgun Injury Prevention Act allows any interested person to bring an action in US district court to enforce the Act or restrain violations. The court may award attorney's fees to a prevailing plaintiff. Compliance with the Act does not relieve liability under common law or State statutory law. Compliance with the Handgun Injury Prevention Act or any orders/regulations issued under it does not exempt a person from liability under common law or State statutory law. The failure of the Secretary to take authorized action under the Act is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties may be imposed on those notified of violating the Act. Under the Handgun Injury Prevention Act, compliance does not exempt from liability under common law or State statutory law. Criminal penalties may be imposed on those knowingly violating the Act. SEC. 9. NO EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not override State laws unless they are inconsistent with it, and only to the extent of the inconsistency. State laws providing greater protection to children regarding handguns are not considered inconsistent with this Act. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms such as "handgun discharge protection product," "children," "licensed importer," "licensed manufacturer," "licensed dealer," "Secretary," and "handgun."
